titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Monday IV:30— I walked this morning before breakfast with my Son John to Judge Cranch’s on the Capitol Hill, where he and John witnessed the Execution by me, and took my acknowledgement of a Deed from the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to David T. Brigham, Isaac Davis and Perley Goddard, of upwards of 500 Acres of Land at Princeton— I had received the Deed from my Son Charles, yesterday, and despatched it to him by the Mail with a short Letter this Evening— I received also a Letter from W. Thomas at Plymouth with the name of Ezraas a claimant for a Revolutionary Pension in addition to those he had sent me before. I went to the Pension Office, and gave to James L Edwards the Commissioner this name, and enquired of all the rest whose names I had given to the Secretary of War on Saturday— Edwards said the Papers had been found; they were now in hand; and he would give me information concerning them—tomorrow or the next day. The Papers in one case only, that of Ephraim Lucas had not been found.— I wrote Letters to Stephen Bates, to thank him for returning to me a Letter which I had written last April from Philadelphia to John B. Davis, and after his death, was in the draw of a desk, sold with the effects of his— Bates procured and returned it to me— I wrote also to Christopher Slocom at Medway, and sent him a copy of a remonstrance against his petition for a new Post-Office— I was writing almost the whole day, and made little progress in preparation for my departure— The Election in Massachusetts for the Members of the House of Representatives to the 23d. Congress, took place this day. I received from the Telegraph Office 100 copies of the Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures.— Mr Coxe took the House in F. Street last occupied by Commodore Patterson— My mind is under severe exercise.
2. IV:15. Tuesday.

As I copy the Manuscripts of Masonry from W. L. Stone, new reflections occur to me, and new proofs of the pernicious character of that Institution— I received an order from John A. Smith for the payment of 500 dollars of the bequest from my father to him—which I accepted— Despatched about 40 copies of the Minority Report, and received one from my Son Charles of the Edition printed at Boston, by Eastburn, under the direction as he informs me of I. P. Davis, Abbott Laurence and T. H. Perkins—for gratuitous circulation 5000 copies. He says he believes there are two or three other Editions— Mr Walsh writes me that they will circulate many thousand copies of the Supplement to the National Gazette containing the Report. The Hingham Gazette of Friday last, has several electioning Essays pro and con—but the National Republican Convention at Scituate on Thursday the 28th. unanimously, by Ballot, nominated me as a Candidate for the 23d. Congress—and passed a handsome resolution of approbation of my Service in the 22d. I have done them injustice, by my Suspicions, which were founded on the attacks against me in the Hingham Gazette, unanswered; the cold and doubting neutrality of the Old-Colony Memorial, and the shyness of the Pilgrim— These are all the newspapers published in the District, excepting the We The People, an Antimasonic Paper, of scarcely any circulation, the zeal of which was rather
adapted to stimulate and exasperate the Masonic opposition. The party adverse to Anti-Masonry in the District, is 3/5 of the whole vote— Not quite half consisting of National Republicans, and about one seventh of Jacksonians— These have nominated Jedidiah Lincoln, whom I do not know— There is an Article in the Hingham Gazette, recommending to the adversaries of Antimasonry, National Republicans to vote for the Jackson Candidate, if they present a decent man— It is probable that the greater number of them will not vote at all— I went to the Clerk’s office of the House of Representatives, but Mr Clarke was not there— In the Library I consulted Dinsdale’s Isocrates and Bossuet’s Universal History— Called at P. Thompson’s the Booksellers, and asked him to send me 40 copies of Dermot MacMorrogh— He had not so many, but sent me after dinner six Copies with the last volume of the Encyclopedia Americana, 13th I stopped at the Office of the Secretary of the Colonization Society, and took several of their Reports for W. Plumer junr. who had written to me to procure them for him— In the Evening I wrote to Dr. Waterhouse.
3. IV. Wednesday.

Rain all the morning, so as to confine me almost to the house— I walked nevertheless to the U.S. Branch Bank, where my Son John had paid the draft of J. A. Smith for 500 dollars; and where I took my Bank Book that the entry might be made both to my debet and credit, for a record of the transaction— After dinner the rain subsided, and at the beginning of the Evening I walked round the Capitol Hill— I had devoted two hours before breakfast to the Masonic Manuscript and three or four afterwards in addressing copies of the Minority Report to the Members of the Massachusetts Legislature— I sent a copy to each member of the Council, after having much difficulty, and consuming much time in ascertaining their residences. In the number of We the People which came this day, the Letter of the Anti-Masonic Members of the Massachusetts Legislature to me, dated in January, and my answer dated the 22d. of March, are both published; I suppose taken from the daily Boston Advocate—it ascertained to me the fact, of which I had some doubt—whether my Answer had been received, before the adjournment of the Legislature. They adjourned on the 28th.— We the People has also the address of the Anti-Masonic Convention which nominated me for Election to the 23d. Congress— I did propose to write a Letter to W. Plumer junr, but found myself unable to write, in the Evening owing to weariness from my walk.
4. V. Thursday.

Labouring yet on the Masonic Manuscript. After Breakfast I began a Letter to W. Plumer junr. intending as usual that it should be short, and as usual too finding it run into length— In the midst of it I was obliged to suspend it upon receiving from the War Department a budget of Certificates for Revolutionary Pensionary Pensioners— They were answers to almost all the applications that I had made at the instance of Jacob H. Loud, Zacheus Bartlett and William Thomas. Some of the cases are suspended for further vouchers— Of one, it is said there is no record of a claim at the Department, and one upon which no answer is given; but there were fourteen Certificates for Pensions, seven of which I enclosed with a Letter to
Zacheus Bartlett, and seven in one to William Thomas; both of which I despatched by the Mail this Evening; under cover with a number of the Temperance Recorder, from Albany, to each of them— Walk round the Capitol Hill— Heavy Thunder-gust and rain this Evening— The Concord Yeoman which came this day says that the Masons in Plymouth County have actually nominated the Revd Joseph Richardson for election to Congress in opposition to me— It is remarkable that neither of the Papers printed in the County of Plymouth contains the nomination. It must I think have been in some Boston Paper.
5. IV. Friday. [symbols]

Finished the copy of the second of the Masonic Manuscripts, received from W. L. Stone. They are authentic documents of the seven degrees of Masonry from the Entered Apprentice to the Royal Arch Companion as they existed in Connecticut in 1811 and 1812— I went to the General Land Office, and there delivered to the Commissioner, the power of Attorney from Josiah Holmes, Mary Holmes and Lois Holmes to me, to surrender the Land Warrant N. 795 for 100 Acres issued to them as Heirs of Sylvester Holmes; and to receive Scrip and to sell and assign it for the same— Mr Heyward the Commissioner assured me the Scrip should be issued tomorrow— I called next at the Office of the Secretary of War, but he was absent— I went therefore to Mr J. L. Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions to enquire of the case of the claim of Nathaniel Thomas, which was omitted from the list which he had sent me yesterday. He said the claim had been admitted, and the certificate sent to Mr J. B. Thomas the 22d of last Month— Of this I despatched a Letter to Mr W. Thomas.— Walk to the Capitol, and call at the Office of Mr Clark, Clerk to the House of Representatives— I enquired for the public documents of the last Session, and he ordered 25 more copies of the Minority Report of the Committee of Manufactures, but no others were ready— These I received this Evening. I finished a Letter to W. Plumer junr, and wrote one to John B. Hearn, Chilicothe, Ohio; a very young man, entirely a Stranger to me; but who has written to me repeatedly to ask for copies of publications written by me— I received no Newspaper from Boston; but there were extracts in New York and Philadelphia Papers from the Boston Atlas of Tuesday— The Election at Boston failed— F. C Gray lacking about 140 votes to be carried— The Atlas says that E. Everett in Middlesex and J. Q. Adams in Plymouth, were of course elected.
6. IV:15. Saturday
Hale Philo.

I want the art of writing short Letters. This morning I began one to James Moorhead of Mercer, Pennsylvania, intending to write four lines, and wrote four pages. I send to him a copy of Dermot and of the minority Report, with one of twenty copies of the Temperance Recorder, which I have received from Albany to circulate. A Clerk from the General Land-Office, named M’Intyre, brought me two Scrips, one for 80 and one for 20. Acres of Lands, receivable as 125 dollars at any of the Land-Offices in Ohio, Indiana, or Illinois, issued in the names of Josiah Holmes, Mary Holmes and Lois Holmes, heirs of Sylvester Holmes, signed by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Commissioner of the General Land Office; and he took of me a receipt for the same. He said if I wished
to sell the scrips he would send a person to me who would purchase them. I asked him what the market price of them was—he said he believed the highest price given was one dollar and 12 1/2 Cents an Acre. I desired him to send the purchaser— Mr Philo Hale soon afterwards came, and I assigned to him the Scrips for which he paid me 42 dollars 50 Cents— My Power of Attorney remains as a Voucher at the General Land-Office— I deposited the money at the U.S. Branch Bank and took an Order for the amount, upon the Cashier of the Branch at Boston— I received a Letter from Jonathan Parker of Plympton containing names of fifteen applicants for Pensions, whose papers he says were sent last August to the War Department, and upon which they have received no answers. I took the Letter to the Secretary of War, and left it with him, requesting him that if possible the cases might be decided and the Certificates or answers sent to me before next Wednesday that being the day upon which I propose to depart upon my homeward journey. He promised that it should be done— I reminded him of my request for copies of the papers relating to the pursuit of Coll. William King at the instance of the acting Governor of New-York, Genl. Pitcher in 1828. to which attention he said should be paid. There was a person engaged with him in business so that I made my visit short, but I called at the Pension Office; mentioned to Mr Edwards the 15 new cases, I had left with the Secretary and my wish to have the answers upon them before next Wednesday—to which he promised his co-operation. I then went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, to enquire if they had any Boston Newspapers, with returns of the Elections for Congress, but they had received this day no papers from Boston at-all— I had received the Boston Press of Tuesday, containing the returns of five towns in the County of Norfolk, but none from the County of Plymouth— Gales promised to send me the Boston Papers that he should receive to-morrow— Returning home, I stopped at P. Thompson’s and settled an account with him for the last three Volumes of the Encyclopaedia Americana. I asked him why he had sent me only six copies of Dermot MacMorrogh— He said he had but eight left—that he had sent me six; retaining only two; one of which he had sold yesterday. We dined, my wife and myself—my Son John and Mary with Mr Thomas B. Johnson, and came home late in the Evening.
7. Sunday IV. Easter.

I attended public worship this Morning at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith, from Romans 8.7. [“]Because the carnal mind is enmity against God: for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed can be.”— The sixth and last of the Series of Discourses upon the same text— The particular argument of this day was the necessity of Repentance— But the Subject had been before exhausted— I took my grand child Mary Louisa with me— It being Easter Sunday, and the Morning Service at St. John’s Church of course very long, there was no Afternoon Service there. Mr Smith gave notice that the Evening Service there would henceforth commence at half past seven— I went there about seven which was too early— I therefore attempted to walk to Mr Frye’s—but it grew dark; there had been rain the Streets were slippery with mud, and it began to rain again— I made some progress beyond Mr Johnson’s House, and then gave
it up and turned back. I went in to Mr Johnson’s and spent a couple of hours with him— When I left his house, I found it pouring with rain; blowing a heavy gale, the Streets over shoes with mud, and darkness that might be felt— His black Servant John came home with me— I could scarcely have got home alone.— It was near eleven when I came in.— I had written a couple of short Letters in the course of the day—and commenced one to Edward Livingston, upon Masonry—to be much reflected on before finally sent— Perhaps to be suppressed— Finished reading the Second Book of Samuel this Morning.
8. IV:30. Monday.

The fatigue of last Night gave me a sounder and longer repose than usual, and I rose at half past four.— Received a Letter from Dr Zacheus Bartlett of Plymouth, with more applications for Revolutionary Claimants of Pensions— The papers of Ansell Harlow with additional vouchers were sent back to me, and a Letter from Dr Bartlett to J. L. Edwards in favour of William Cornish— I took them to Mr Edwards, who promised immediate attention to them. Gave me a blank Declaration for Cornish to fill up, and mentioned that the papers of all the claims I had brought in on Saturday, were before the Secretary of War for his signature— I called at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury; and made some enquiries of Mr M’Lane, respecting the execution of the act of last Session for modifying the Tariff Act of 14. July 1832— He says that by virtue of a power conferred upon him by that Act, he is preparing regulations for reducing the specific to ad valorem duties; and that he will send me a copy of them when prepared. I spoke to him of Mr Hassler and his labours in the progress of the Survey of the Coast— He said that he had yielded to Hassler’s objections against the appointment of a board which he had proposed; consisting of Asbury Dickens, an Officer of Engineers and an Officer of the Navy to superintend the work, and that Hassler was gone to commence the operations of the Season— I next went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, where Mr Gales gave me several Boston Newspapers of Thursday last, containing the Returns of the Congressional Elections— Choate, Everett, and Davis, certainly re-elected— Bates, Grennell and Briggs doubtless— W. Baylies elected in Bristol— Dearborn fails in Norfolk and Middlesex. F. C. Gray in Boston— Cushing in North Essex.— Read in Barnstable is chosen almost without opposition: and in twenty of 24 Towns, constituting the 12th. District, more than three fourths of the votes are for me— This disposition of the People, is a subject to me of the most ardent gratitude to Heaven— I met on the avenue Mr Bibb, a Senator from Kentucky, and at the door of the Intelligencer Office Thomas R. Mitchell of South Carolina, who is in no hurry to go home. He said he would send me a copy of his circular to his Constituents— The afternoon and Evening were oppressively sultry— I received a packet of Pension Certificates from the Department of War—but there was one missing.
9. IV:30 Tuesday.

Mr Smith called this morning and gave me a packet of Letters for his brother John A. who has opened an Office as N 10 Veasey Street, in the city of New York— I called at the Pension Office of the War-Department to enquire concerning two of the claims for Pensions in Jonathan Parker’s Letter, upon which decisive answers had not been given— After receiving satisfactory explanations from him, I went to the U.S. Branch Bank and ascertained the balance due to Elijah Bisbee jr. Admr of Elijah Bisbee; arrears of interest upon United States notes to be one dollar and thirty two Cents—
This is the sum to receive which a power of Attorney from Bisbee was sent me more than a year since, which Power I mislaid and have never been able to find. I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and enquired of Mr Seaton whether he would publish a Letter from me to Edward Livingston, as Grand High Priest of the General Royal Arch Chapter of the United States— He somewhat hesitated— I told him it was an answer to an address delivered by Mr Livingston, at his Installation as Grand High Priest, which was published in the Intelligencer of 22. April 1830.— He said that might be a reason for admitting it; although they had generally excluded pieces relating to the Masonic controversy, on both sides, to avoid getting entangled in it— He said he would look over my Letter and either publish it, or send it back to me with a written answer giving the reasons for declining so to do. After dinner I walked with my Son John to Mr Frye’s— He was not at home. We sat an hour with Mrs Frye, and on returning home found Mr Frye at our house— Mr John Connell came in soon after, and they spent the Evening with us— I answered the Letter from Jonathan Parker and sent him the Certificates which I had received from the War Department upon the cases mentioned in his Letter.
10. IV:30. Wednesday.

I had intended to leave Washington this day, but was unable to complete my preparations for departure, and after all must leave my affairs here totally unsettled; owing to the truly distressing situation in which my family has been almost the whole winter; and owing to my own weakness—of which all that I can say is that it is a weakness of tender affection— But I am compelled to go, leaving my Affairs unsettled— The prospect of passing two more winters here affords me some slight apology, but not a sufficient one— I went again to the Pension Office, and received from Mr Edwards the Certificate for the daughters of Ansel Harlow.— Then to the Office of the National Intelligencer to enquire what they had determined to do, with my Letter to the General Grand High Priest Edward Livingstone.— It was already printed for the Intelligencer of to-morrow. I revised the proof of the Latin quotation from Cicero, which was much mutilated. The remainder of the day, I was much occupied in preparing for my departure— But wrote to Dr Zacheus Bartlett at Plymouth and sent him the Certificate for the daughters of Ansell Harlow, and a blank Declaration for William Cornish— I wrote also an answer to a Letter from Mrs Hay at New-York.— Judge Cranch called to see me this afternoon.
11. IV:30. Thursday— From Washington to Baltimore.

All the former part of this day was absorbed in that most anxious occupation of the last preparations for departure upon a long journey— They seem to me to become more and more irksome, at every repetition. The Intelligencer had my Letter to Edward Livingston— I cut it out of the paper, and enclosed it, with a Copy of the Boston Stereotype Edition of my Letters on the Entered Apprentice’s Oath, and the Letter to B. Cowell on political anti-masonry; and I sent the whole under a cover directed to him— I made four copies of it up to be despatched also to several persons by the Mail— Balanced my account at the U.S. Branch Bank—dined at One O’Clock and at two the Stage for Baltimore took me up at my
door—we proceeded to Mrs Freeman’s and took in two of her nieces of that name, daughters of Major Freeman, going to Baltimore.— Then to Mr W. B. Bradley, who came in with his wife and family; a Miss Turner going to Philadelphia, and Coll. Worth of the Army— We came on and at eight in the Evening alighted at Belzhoover’s tavern in Baltimore— At Merrill’s, the Waterloo Hotel, 12 Miles short of Baltimore we met several Stages on the way to Washington. Mr Temple of Vermont, and Mr Hector Craig of New-York were two of the Passengers— Peach-trees in full blossom the whole way— Mrs Bradley was ill on our arrival at Baltimore—I had taken with me David Brewster’s Life of Sir Isaac Newton, of which I read several chapters. At Baltimore I sent a boy to Mr Niles to ask him to call and see me; but he was not at home, and after making a worse than useless supper I retired to bed.
12. V. Friday.— From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

Embarked in the Steamer George Washington, Captain Trippe the younger— On my way from the Tavern, Mr Niles overtook me, and went with me to the Boat.— He has promised to republish my Minority Report in his Register— I asked him to print it from the Congressional document for the sake of the quotation from Cicero in the Note, which he said he would. I promised to send him one of the documents from Philadelphia— He apologized for not having come to me last Night, as he had been detained by the death of Mr Meeteer— We loosed from the wharf five minutes after six— The boat was full of passengers— I suppose at least 150. Among them besides Mr Bradley and his family and Coll Worth, were Mr John H. Eaton and his wife: Mr Duff Green and I believe his daughter, Andrew Wallace the Centenarian Scot—Professor Henry Ware, and his wife, Dr Waterhouse’s daughter, returning from a sanatory excursion to Alexandria, and an Englishman named Messenger, now residing at New-York— Also a little band of Italian Musicians with two Harps, one Violin, a Clarinette and a flute, who enlivened the passage with much discourse of sweet Music. I got into a discussion with Duff Green, upon the Tariff, Domestic Manufactures and Protection, Slave labour and consolidation, which attracted round us a circle of listeners, to my great annoyance. Another discussion arose between Mr Messenger, and another passenger, upon the project of Earl Gray’s Ministry to emancipate the Slaves in the British West-Indies, from which discussion, I with some difficulty kept myself aloof— I had a conversation with Coll. Worth, who is excessively discontented— Told me that Coll Thayer was actually removed from the Superintendancy of the Military Academy at West-Point; also Captain Hitchcock, the second in command. That the Successor in the course of Routine will be a Captain de Russi, but that the Establishment will be broken up— Worth told me also that Amos Kendall and Van Ness the Mayor of Washington had undertaken to investigate certain charges of peculation against Commodore Rodgers, and went to him at the Office of the Navy Commissioners— That Rodgers told them, if he had been guilty of Official Misdemeanour he had a right to a trial by his Peers— That he should not hold himself accountable to them— That there was the door of the Office, out of which he recommended to them to retire, to save him and them the mortification of his kicking them out, which he should certainly otherwise do— They sneaked off and then an Article of the Globe disclaimed any intention of trying the Commodore, and pretending that the enquiry was only of some malversation of his Clerks— Andrew Wallace, the descendant from Robert the brother of Sir William, fought over again his battles of Preston Pans and Culloden, and at the suggestion of Mr Messenger, a collection of a few dollars was made for the old man among the Passengers— I had a Conversation with Professor and Mrs Ware, after dinner upon Sir Walter Scott and Shakespear—Homer and Virgil, Lord Byron,
the Waverley Novels, Tom Jones and Gil blas— Mr Eaton came up and spoke to me several times— He told me that on the day of the conflagration of the Treasury Department he had picked up in the Street an order signed by the Secretary of the Treasury the day before, for a repayment of duties, under the act of the last Session— The order had been blown off by the wind from the perishing Edifice, and though somewhat scorched was still entire— We landed at Frenchtown at 11 O’Clock, and crossed the Peninsula to Newcastle in the Railway Cars impelled by the locomotive engine in fifty minutes—16 miles— But we had flakes of fire floating about us in the Cars the whole time with the allowance of two minutes for the slackening of speed at the departure and arrival we travell’d at the rate of a mile every three minutes; and were precisely one hour from landing at Frenchtown from one Steamer to leaving the wharf at Newcastle in the other— We landed at 4. O’Clock at Philadelphia, and I took my lodgings at the United States Hotel— At 6. I called at Mr Nicholas Biddle’s, but he was not at home; then at Mr Walsh’s and spent an hour with him— Then at Mr John Sergeant’s— He was going out with his two elder daughters to a tea-party— I came home to my lodgings and wrote till eleven, to bring up arrears of diary, and press Edward Livingston. I met at Mr Walsh’s a Frenchman by the name of Picot— Walsh told me he had issued 9000 copies of the Supplement to the National Gazette containing the Report and the United States Gazette issued it in a Supplement also.— Walsh spoke also of my Letter to Edward Livingston; but not in the same tone of approbation— He disclaims being at all under Masonic influence, but has not published the Letter, nor will he publish it.
13. V:30. Saturday.

It was a day of perpetual motion—my first visitor was Mr Southard with his Son— He has returned to the practice of the Law, since his election to the Senate of the United States has vacated his Office as Governor of New Jersey— He is much engaged in the business of the Courts, and came accidentally to this City yesterday— He returned home after calling upon me this morning. The other visitors named in the margin followed in the course of the Morning, excepting Mr Stephens, and Mr Vaughan who came in the Evening. Stephens is a Welsh Clergyman who was one of our fellow passengers in the Boats from Baltimore yesterday; and who fixed his attention very closely upon me. Whenever this happens, I find it always and in some purpose of the observer; and not pour l’amour de mes beaux yeux. He spoke to me yesterday, and walked up with me from the boat. Told me he was a foreigner; that he had heard me at Boston deliver an Eulogy upon Mr Monroe; and that he was naturally desirous of seeing distinguished persons, as in Europe People always wished to see kings and princes. This Evening he came to ask a contribution for building Welsh Churches—(more than one) somewhere near Utica in the State of New-York— He had certificates of his respectability, and of his being employed in that service; but I declined giving him a contribution— I was with Mr Biddle great part of the day. Twice at the Bank, but our Conversation was continually interrupted there by persons, coming to him upon business—and we strolled to Carpenters Hall, where sat the Congress of 1774—and to Carey and Lea’s Bookseller’s shop, where he went in search for Books upon Education. I dined with Mr Abbott Lawrence and his family who are at the same Hotel— Met there Mr Leaming, Mr Walsh, a Son of William Sullivan, just returned from China; a young Mr Amory, settled here in Philadelphia— Mr Biddle came with a Carriage at 4 O’Clock, and took me out
to the place upon which the Girard College is to be built— It is already staked out— There are 45 Acres of Land, but the directions of the Will are so particular and minutious that they are compelled to erect their building in oblique direction to the Streets of the Squares, discomposing the Symmetry of the City— I met there Mr Richards late Mayor of the City, and several other members of the board of Trustees— I had much Conversation with Mr Biddle; though very desultory upon the manner of organizing this Institution; upon which Mr Biddle as President of the Board of Trustees has consulted me.— Upon two points especially he desired my opinions—how to secure to the children a religious education, and to some of them a Classical Education— After quitting the College ground, we paid a short visit to the penitentiary which I had visited when here last Spring.— Among the convicts I conversed again with the remarkable one; William Napier— The North-Carolina man has been pardoned by Governor Wolf at the solicitation of Messrs. Carson and Speight— It was between 8 and 9 in the Evening when I got home to my Apartment at the Hotel.
14. VI. Sunday

Mr Cowperthwait called this morning and accompanied me to the Unitarian Church, with Mr and Mrs Lawrence; where we heard a Sermon from Mr Furness from Psalm 145.9. “The Lord is good to all, and his tender mercies are over all his works.” The argument was a special Providence, beneficent to every individual and inferrible from the blessings which never fail to flow from obedience to the will of God. This position was original to me, and was sustained with great force and ingenuity— He began by asserting that the belief of a Supreme being, and of a general superintending Providence was useless and unprofitable unless accompanied with that of a special Providence providing for the happiness of every individual— And the proof of this he inferred from the fact that Virtue never loses its reward—but is always conducive to happiness— Dr Kirkland, late President of Harvard University was at Church and as I came out Mr Thomas Hulme accosted me, and invited me to call at his house— I met also Miss Mease, and received afterwards several visitors at my chambers— Among them Mr Maury heretofore our Consul at Liverpool, and Mr Duponceau. At 3. O’Clock, I went and dined with R. Peters, with a party of friends— After dinner, visited Mrs Roberdeau, with whom I found her two daughters, Mary and Susan— The third, Selina, has not yet returned from Washington.— My next call was at the house of Mr Hulme, but he was not at home.— Then I went and spent an hour with Mr. J. Sergeant, and finished the Evening at Mr Leaming’s; where I met Mr Abbott Lawrence, and President Quincy of Harvard University, who has been to visit the Coal mines, in the vicinity of this City— He proceeds on his return home to-morrow Morning— Mr Leaming’s brother is a member of the Legislature of Pennsylvania; and he himself is an active and intelligent member of the Pennsylvania Society for the improvement of Arts and Manufactures— The Supporters of these Interests are in great perplexity, and under alarm, at the condition and prospects of the Country. The Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures has been very satisfactory to them, and they have circulated it very extensively— Returned to my lodgings about 11. at Night.
15. VI. Monday.

Mr N. Biddle had persuaded Mr Lawrence, and me to remain at Philadelphia, over this day; to dine with him— Mr Thomas Hulme called upon me immediately after Breakfast. He is an Englishman, born at Manchester; but has been many years settled here, and has amassed a fortune by manufacturing— He is much devoted to that interest; and he has a project for emancipating the Slaves of our Southern States and making compensation at the public expense to their owners— And for offering to the South an amicable separation of the States as an alternative.— This is a subject upon which people here have brought themselves to reason very coolly. Mr Fletcher came and invited Mr Lawrence and his family and me to visit his two Manufactures—one of Silver and gold plate; and the other of engraved steel cylinders for printing Cotton— The Plate is very neatly wrought; and the cylinders curiously engraved. Mr and Mrs Lawrence with a boy and girl, and Mr and Mrs Samuel Lawrence accompanied us in viewing the works of plate, but not those of the Cylinders— Mr Hulme was with us at both— I called then upon R. Walsh and passed about two hours with him— He shewed me a quarto volume of Palsgrave on the British Constitution. He gave me a Globe, containing a burlesque parody in verse of part of my published Letter to Edward Livingston— He told me that he would republish the Letter, or any other that I should address to Livingston upon that subject, but that they wanted to keep me confined to Calhoun and the Tariff—as Subjects more important, and more worthy of me. I had much conversation with him upon the proposed organization of the Girard College, the Saint Sulpicians who educated him—the Jesuits, and the Philosophy of Plato— I afterwards called twice at the United States Bank to see Mr Biddle but he was not there— Met at the door, Mr Horn, and Dr Mease who promised to send me, and did send me some Lima beans for seeds— I finished a second Letter for publication, addressed to Edward Livingston— Directed it to Gales and Seaton, and enclosed it under a cover to my wife— It is too hastily written, and ought perhaps not to have been published without severe revisal— Dined with Mr. N. Biddle— Went with Mr Abbott Lawrence. Met there R. Rush, who has just removed from York to the neighbourhood of Philadelphia—Dr Kirkland—Judge Hopkinson—R. Peters—and some others. Mr Richards Mayor of the City came in after dinner. Conversation with him, on the organization of the Girard College and the difficulty of carrying into execution the intentions of the founder, and of giving the boys a good religious education, and some of them classical accomplishments. Mr Rush took me to my lodgings about nine in the Evening, and I gave him a National Intelligencer containing my Letter to Edward Livingston which he had not seen— I packed up for departure to-morrow Morning.
16. V. Tuesday— From Philadelphia to New-York.

At half-past six this Morning we embarked in the Steam-boat—landed at eleven at Bordentown. There took the Railway Cars, which here travel with horses, having no locomotive. At one we took again the Steamer New Philadelphia at Amboy, and at half-past three in the afternoon landed at New-York— Mr Abbott Lawrence and his family were in company; but his brother Samuel Lawrence, with his bride, who was a Miss Turnbull of Baltimore, remain at Philadelphia, to come on to-morrow— Professor Douglas formerly of West-Point, but now of the new University at New-York was also this day one of our fellow-travellers, and reminded me that he had been introduced to me some years since, when I was in the Presidential house— He spoke of Coll. Thayer’s resigning the Superintendent’s
Station at the West-Point Academy, and thought it would have an unfavourable effect upon the Institution— On reaching New-York, I went with Mr Lawrence to Bunker’s, intending to take lodgings there with him— But they had just, spare room for him and his family, and none for me— I thence went to the City-Hotel, where they were so full, that they could give me at first only a bedchamber so shabby that I could not put up with it—one of their lodgers however went off to Albany, and they gave me his bed-room; about the size of a penitentiary cell; without fire-place; but a great improvement on the other. I soon went out, in search of John A. Smith’s Office, N. 10. Vesey Street; which I found, with his partner in it— He went with me to meet him at his lodgings, at the Clinton Hotel. I met him with a Cousin of his, Son of his Aunt at Philadelphia— I looked at a Bed-chamber, at the Clinton-Hall, but it was no better than the one I occupied at the City-Hotel— I agreed to go with the Smith’s to the Italian Opera— Mr C. A. Davis called upon me, and invited me to go with him— We all went together— The performance was Otello—the music by Rossini—for the benefit of Signora Pedrotti the Prima donna, who performed the part of Desdemona— The music as my old friend Count Maistre used to say, has no colour— There is no interest in the drama— The jealous furies of an ugly blackamoor at the supposed infidelity of a beautiful daughter of a Venetian Senator are not more pathetic in Song than in Story. I never relished Othello— Otello is not more amusing— Signora Pedrotti sung and acted very well; but there was no enthusiasm, no good songs and much dull recitative— The House was full, and fashionable— The Play is in three Acts— No afterpiece, and I was at my lodgings in bed, before eleven O’Clock— My raking life has already brought my eyes into jeopardy— The lights in the house were so oppressive, that I was obliged to shade my forehead with my hand almost the whole Evening.
17. VI. Wednesday.

My suffering eyes debar me from reading, writing or early rising— How large a portion of my life, I have wasted in careless indolence!— How much I lose now in compulsive indolence! My nephew Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams arrived here this Morning in the Steamer Boston from Providence— He has had a short furlough to visit his friends, and returns now to proceed to Pittsburg where he is to be stationed.— But he is first going up the North river to visit his brother Isaac Hull at West Point; and the De Wint family at Fish-kill Landing. After Breakfast I called at the Office of the Commercial Advertiser, and saw Coll. William L. Stone— His partner Mr Clark was with him— He was the person who wrote the Masonic Manuscripts which Stone sent me, and of which I have taken a copy— I asked him to let me keep the Originals—to which both he and Mr Clark assented— I told them I should probably publish them— Clarke said he should wish that the name of Chief Justice Hoemer should not be used—nor that of Mr Moseley; but otherwise did not object to the publication— I told Mr Stone that I had not given up the cause of abolishing the Masonic Obligations, and hoped he would not give it up—but he was very lukewarm upon the Subject— He said the whole concern of Masonry and Anti-Masonry was going down in the State of New-York as fast as it could— That all interest upon the subject was rapidly subsiding— That the Masons were giving up their Lodges, and the Anti-Masons would never again muster so strong a vote as they had the last Fall— He seemed inclined however to publish a cheap edition of his own book; with my Letters to him upon the Entered Apprentices Oath, and those to Edward Livingston, by way of Supplement or Appendix— I asked him
if he could furnish me with the proceedings of the Grand Lodge of the State of New-York at their recent Meeting at Albany— He could not— I enquired if he knew what number of Lodges there had been in the State— He said about six hundred— My next visit was to Mrs C. A. Davis, who urged me much to go this Evening to a Soirée, a small musical party given by Miss Douglas, the Sister of James Monroe’s wife, and who has lately returned from Europe— Coming back to my Lodgings, where my bedchamber was again changed, I found Mr Redwood Fisher, Editor of the New-York National Advocate, a paper much in the manufacturing interest, and with whom I had a conversation of perhaps two hours. He approves very highly the Minority Report, and I have been so much flattered, and by so many persons upon that paper, that I am ashamed of myself for being elated with it; and duly grateful that it has been the means of softening many bitter animosities against me. Mr Fisher invited me to take tea at his house, this Evening— Mr C. A. Davis came and engaged me to go with him this evening to the Soirée of Miss Douglas— I had intended to proceed this afternoon on my journey home; but the weather was inauspicious, and the Benjamin Franklin was the boat. I concluded to stay till to-morrow— I had several visitors—John A. Smith and his Cousin Lieutenant T. B. Adams were with me part of the day— I breakfasted and dined at the Public Table and could not but remark the precipitation which many of the boarders used in swallowing their Meals— A Mr Dewey, part Editor of the New-York whig an anti-masonic Newspaper, and two other persons, one of them Editor of an Anti-Masonic Newspaper at Newark, New Jersey came, and had some project of republishing my Letters to Edward Livingston, which I could not encourage— They are to call again at ten to-morrow Morning— The Revd. Dr. Matthews came, and I promised to call at his House to-morrow at Noon— Mr Fisher walked with me to his house, and I took tea with him and his family— I had engaged to go with Mr Davis to Miss Douglas’s; and he came for me at a quarter after nine—but I did not get home till near ten from Mr Fishers— So I lost the Soirée— Joseph Blunt called upon me, yesterday and this day— I left a Card at Mr Philip Hone’s— My eyes were somewhat relieved; but the bustle of the day was harrassing.
18. VI. Thursday— Steamer Boston from New-York— Long-Island Sound.

Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams went this morning for West Point— I went to the house of Mr Sidney Brooks— He was not at home, but I found there the Rev’d Mr Frothingham of Boston— I next attempted to find Mr. S. L. Gouverneur’s house but missed it, the name of the Street having been changed— Returned to my lodgings, and met there Mr Ward and Mr Dewey Anti-Masonics, and Mr Fisher of the distinguished and extinguished order of National Republicans— Mr Ward proposed to employ me as Counsel in support of some claim that he has before the Legislature of Rhode-Island, and I regretted my inability to assume the charge— I had visits also from Judge Thompson, Chancellor Kent and Dr Wainwright. At noon I called on Dr Matthews who is still sangwine in the project of forming a National Institute or Academy of Sciences to be located at New-York, and at the head of which he is desirous of placing me. He strongly
urged my attendance at a Meeting which he proposes should be held here in July— I could not absolutely refuse; but I believe the Meeting would be of little use— I apprehend that the project for a scientific Academy is chimerical; and if not, I know I am not fitted to preside over such an Institution— Their new University has been hitherto successful beyond my most sanguine expectations— Mr Lawrence, Mr Frothingham, and Henry Brooks called on me— At dinner, at the public table, I met a very old acquaintance—Mr Nicholas Saltus— At 5 in the afternoon I came on board the Steamboat Boston, Captain Comstock, and she immediately loosened from the wharf— Weather fine— I thought there was not a Soul on board, save the Captain whom I knew— But in the Evening I was accosted by Mr John Whipple of Providence, who introduced to me his two daughters— The boat speeded magnificently through Hell-gate, where the tide was low, and the streams boiling in eddies round the rocks— I was glad to have got away from the more boiling tourbillon of the Cities, where all is vanity, even when it is not vexation of Spirit; and where my own vanity is alternately flattered and mortified till I long for repose— The water was smooth, and the sky fair till I retired to my birth about ten in the Evening, upwards of sixty miles from New-York.
19. V. Friday— Point Judith— Providence— Boston.

The night was tranquil, but I had little sleep— At five this Morning I rose, and on deck found Block-Island upon one Quarter, and the Light-House of Point-Judith on the other— At half past six, some of our Passengers landed at Newport, and at nine the rest of us landed at Providence— They put me in the Mail Pilot Stage; with six or seven Passengers, not one of whom I knew, but whose conversation was all about transactions in Wall-Street—freight the mother of wages, and good men of one hundred sents to the dollar— We travelled with speed— My fellow travellers landed at three O’Clock in the afternoon at the Tremont Hotel, and I at my Son Charles’s House, N. 3. Hancock Avenue— I found him, his wife and child, blessed be God, well— They had just dined— They were going in the Evening to the Tremont Theatre, and I went with them. Saw Milman’s Tragedy of Fazio; which I should not have thought any thing could have tempted me to see— Charles Kemble performed the part of Fazio; and his daughter Fanny Kemble that of Bianca— They both pass here for first rate performers, and Fanny Kemble, for a great Beauty, and a great Genius, both of which with the aid of Fashion and Fancy, she is— She is under twenty, and has written a Tragedy, called Francis the first; and performed with splendid success— The Tragedy of Fazio, is very dull and flat; but yet much more supportable than I could have thought possible— The farce was called the boarding house—laughable; without much wit— The house was crowded, and notice was given that in future one half the boxes would be disposed off during the performances of the Kemble’s at Auction— I met some slight acquaintances at the Theatre, and Mr H. G. Otis came round to the box where I was and spoke to me. The Play was over before eleven O’Clock, and I returned to lodge at my Son Charles’s House—
20. V:15. Saturday— From Boston to Quincy.

My reading of the Bible has been suspended since I left Washington, but was resumed this Morning— To read four chapters every day till the lost time shall be redeemed— Began at the 13th. chapter of the 1st. book of Kings. Mr Degrand called to see me immediately after Breakfast— I visited Mr Alexander H. Everett. The condition of parties in the City the State and the Union, is all disjointed; and every where taking a direction to persons.— Everett said the National Republicans would hardly hold their Majority— They had here no rallying point but Masonry and Henry Clay— Clay has left them and there is nothing but Masonry left.— I called next upon Mr Lord, and told him of the number of copies of Dermot MacMorrogh, which I had received from P. Thompson. He said he would furnish the remaining copies to make up one hundred. I enquired the cost of engraving a Portrait—25 dollars on Stone—perhaps 75 on copper— I went to the Office of the Boston Advocate, to see Mr Hallett, but he was gone to Province— I saw there S. Bates, Dr Phelps, Mr Clough, and sundry other Anti-Masons—and obtained the paper containing the account of the proceedings of the General Grand Royal Arch Chapter of the United States at Baltimore last November— The proceedings of the Grand Lodge of New-York at Albany, I could not obtain— I dined with my Son Charles, and immediately after dinner; he came with me out to Quincy— I reached my home at five in the afternoon, grateful for being once more restored to the place of my nativity, under circumstances of signal mercy, and after a journey in which I have been bountifully favoured— Charles returned immediately to Boston— I found Mrs Kirk and her daughter Elizabeth here— And a man whom Charles has engaged to work in the Garden— Found also a Multitude of Letters—among which was the Official Certificate of my Election, as a Member of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 23d. Congress— The Letters and a number of Newspapers occupied me till late in the Evening.
21. V. Sunday. Quincy.

I am to lead for sometime a life of comparative Solitude—but my time is precious. I began last Evening a Letter to my wife, and finished it this day— I heard Mr Alvan Lamson of Dedham, in the Morning from Psalm 14.1. “The fool hath said in his Heart, there is no God.”— But the Discourse was not an argument upon the existence of God— It was a Dissertation to prove that Religion was a natural impulse in the human heart— The afternoon Sermon was from Micah 6.8. “He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the Lord require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly, with thy God”— They were both sensible, well written Sermons; but delivered in a low tone of voice so that the preacher could not be heard over the whole house— I delivered Letters to my brother’s widow, and to Mrs John Greenleaf. At home I read a Sermon of Saurin the 8th. of the second Volume—upon the disasters of Europe— Preached during the War for the Spanish Succession— It was a time of great Calamity, and we have had such
times in our own age— Since the Peace of Ghent now nearly nineteen years, our condition has been of a totally different character— We have had a career of general prosperity such as man upon Earth seldom enjoys, and yet we are not happy.
22. IV:45. Monday.

My first visitor this morning was my Tenant Carr, who came to ask for alterations and repairs upon the farm— Next came Mr George Veazie with a bill of upwards of one hundred dollars for Carpenter’s Work upon the farm, which I was unable to pay and for which I was obliged to give him an order upon Deacon Spear without knowing whether he could or would pay it— These before breakfast— Afterwards a call from the Revd. Mr Whitney, who has lost his wife since I went from hence last November; and then from Mr Bailey of Dorchester, with whom I had a long conversation— After dinner Alpheus Spear came and paid me two Quarters Rent for Mount Wollaston farm— I visited my garden and Nursery, where the first signs of vegetation are appearing, and my young trees have a totally discouraging aspect— Of the fruit trees, hundreds dead, and among them many upon which I had vested hopes— Of the living the greater number so crooked that they never can be good for any thing— All Solomon Thayer’s Oats or wheat sown by Carr or by Alpheus Spear winter killed—upheaved out of the ground and utterly eradicated by the frost— Horse Chesnuts and wild Cherries are the only trees that have any symptom of flourishing, and neither of them is good for anything— One seed only, an apple or a wild cherry was just out of the ground— I spent the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— He had just returned from a Parish-Meeting— By the building of the Stone Meeting-House, they have contracted a debt, which threatens to break up the Parish; and as their Minister Mr Whitney grows old, they grow weary of him— They dislike his Exchanges; they complain of his dulness— A Universalist Church has been built very near the Temple and draws off the Parishioners to a cheaper form of worship— I received a Letter from N. F. Williams of Baltimore, asking for a copy of my Letters on the Entered Apprentice’s Oath, which I sent him—
23. V. Tuesday.

Though less interrupted this day than yesterday, it passed off like that, and left me with nothing done— Luther Spear came about a patch of fence at Mount Wollaston, concerning which he has teazed me these two years— Ibrahim Bartlett, Parish Clerk brought me a written vote adopted at the Parish Meeting yesterday; appointing me Chairman, and twelve others a Committee to devise means, for paying off the debt of the Parish, and for considering the expediency of employing an assistant or Colleague to Mr Whitney, and consulting with him upon the subject—and I was requested to appoint a time and place for the Meeting of the Committee. I appointed accordingly to-morrow Morning ten O’Clock, at the town Hall— Williams the tax-gatherer came to demand again payment of the Parish Assessment upon my Mount Wollaston Estate, for the last year— I declined paying it, and he spoke of advertising it for Sale. I said the Assessors must do as they pleased about it— That Spear the tenant paid a parish tax for the same place, and refused to pay the tax assessed upon it to me, though bound
to pay all the taxes by his lease— Williams said that my refusal to pay that tax had thrown the whole parish into confusion— I said I could not help that—to which he replied that he would not, if he was I.— The truth is the Parish have got deeply into debt by building a Stone Meeting-house at double the cost which they ought to have incurred; and now they are expecting me to extricate them from their difficulties, because my father made them a large donation for the building of the Church, and because I at my own expence, and without a cent of cost to them erected tombs under the Church, and a marble slab within it, as a frail memorial of affection and reverence to my father and mother. Was there sin in this? A merciful God knows— I thought myself performing a solemn duty. Was there no mixture of worldly pride or vanity in my motive? It has brought me into perplexities, from which divine wisdom alone can relieve me, and in which I pray that I may proceed in meekness and humility, and without weakness or folly, or imprudent Passion— I spent the Evening at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s—Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf were there— The weather has been since my return so mild hitherto, that I have had no fires made—but this Evening there was a chill Northeaster, threatening snow.
24. Wednesday. V. 20.

This old man, called upon me this Morning, expecting to receive from me a Certificate for a Revolutionary Pension— But his Petition was to Congress, and was not reached, in the business of the House of Representatives— I gave him now the Instructions from the Secretary of War, to enable him to make application to that Department under the Act ofJune 1832. At 10 O’Clock Mr G. W. Beale called upon me and we went to the town Hall and met the Parish Committee— Present J. Q. Adams, G. W. Beale, Josiah Brigham, Noah Curtis, Thomas Greenleaf, Daniel Greenleaf, Nathan Josselyn, James Newcomb, Samuel Savil, John Souther, and Henry Wood— Absent John M Gourgas and Thomas Taylor— The subjects referred to the Committee were discussed for upwards of two hours.— With regard to the payment of the debt, which amounts to near nine thousand dollars, various proposals were made, and none adopted— The management of the Affairs of the Parish has been very bad, and it is now upon the verge of dissolution— Every body threatens to withdraw from the Parish, to escape from its burdens, and there is nearly three thousand dollars due to the parish for pews, which they have neglected to collect, and great part of which they will lose. To re-instate the affairs of this Parish, either I must devote time, labour and money, or they will go to utter ruin; and how to do it without ruining myself, I know not— There was a proposal to report the expediency of rescinding a Resolution passed two years since, authorising the holders of pews not paid for, to hold them until further order, paying interest upon their debts—but this was not decided— Then there was much discussion of the question concerning a Colleague for Mr Whitney,—and a sub-committee of 3. appointed to confer with him upon the subject— They put me upon this Committee too; but I declined serving; stating that I was entirely satisfied with Mr Whitney, and am besides not here one half the year— I was excused, but there was great difficulty in obtaining a Committee, every one appointed desiring to be excused— At last Captain Souther, Noah Curtis and Mr Brigham were compelled to undertake the task, and the Committee adjourned to meet at 3. O’Clock P.M next Friday to receive the report of the Sub-Committee, and further to prepare for reporting to the Parish— Thus was absorbed one morning upon a business thrust upon me, and to which I see no prospect of end.
After dinner, I wrote until the approach of Sunset, and then went and spent the Evening at Mrs A. Adams’s, my brother’s widow— Miss Martha Marston was with her upon a visit, but none of her children— Her son John Quincy, whom I had undertaken to educate, and who is at her Son in Law Angier’s school at Medford, has an invincible repugnance and incapacity for learning, and will not go to College— The Letters that I brot to her were from her Son Joseph Harrod, Midshipman with Commodore Patterson Dated at Port Mahon 7 and 14. Jany. There were flakes of snow that fell this Morning.
25. V. Thursday.

I received on Tuesday a Letter from Gales and Seaton, returning my second Letter to Edward Livingston Grand High Priest of the General Grand Royal Arch Chapter of the United States, and Secretary of State of the said States, which they decline to publish in the National Intelligencer— I sent it with their Letter to Mr Hallett, and it is published in the Boston Advocate of this Morning— I had also a Letter from Charles Bowen, reminding me of a promise which I made in November last to furnish him something to publish in the token or Literary Souvenir of the present year— I sent him this day, the Plague in the Forest, a Fable— I received also a Letter from Judge Hopkinson, with an argument and authority, for his definition of the word Orphan— These things engross all my time, so that I make little progress in retrieving arrears either of my Correspondence or my Diary. My Son Charles came out this morning from Boston and spent an hour with me, but returned before dinner. I wrote to my wife, and enclosed for her a check for 300 dollars to enable her to come home— This was not to be delayed— I took the Letter to the Post-Office towards Evening, and then went and passed an hour with Mr Whitney— George Vesey was here this morning, and told me that it would cost near 100 dollars to bring the barn on the hill opposite my house down to be placed by the side of the other— I received a Letter from certain democratic individuals at Providence Rhode-Island, of democratic aspect; but perhaps from some other source.
26. V.20. Friday.

Mr Daniel Greenleaf called on me this morning, and invited me to dine with him— I was diverted from the proper occupation of redeeming the arrears of this Diary, by researches, to ascertain the definition of the word Orphan— The Greek Lexicons, Latin Dictionaries, that of the French Academy, the Epistle of James in the New Testament, Calvin’s Lexicon Juridicum, Euripides and the French Don Quixot, were referred to and consulted— A Child who has lost both parents or either is an Orphan; in the strict acceptation of the word— In common parlance an orphan is a fatherless child. I had consumed the morning till noon in these enquiries, when my Son Charles came in from Boston; his wife having gone to her father’s at Medford to spend the day.— We both dined at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s with his brother Thomas— At three in the afternoon we attended the adjourned meeting of the Committee of the Parish; I was obliged to leave Charles to amuse himself in my Library, and he returned to Boston, before the Committee adjourned. They sat till near Sunset— All present excepting Nathan Josselyn, and Henry Wood. The Sub-committee appointed to confer with Mr Whitney reported that they had called upon him on Wednesday, and mentioned to him the dissatisfaction which existed among some of the Parishioners, with some of his Clerical brethren with whom he exchanges; and some complain that they are not able to hear him— They inclined therefore either to settle a Colleague with him, or to employ occasional assistance to him to supply the
pulpit, part of the time— Mr Whitney had asked time to consider the proposition till this day at 2 O’Clock, and then he had declared his willingness to relinquish part of his Salary, to obtain assistance for half the time. By Mr Whitney’s original Settlement in 1800 he was to receive 500 dollars a year— From 1813 to 1816 additional grants were made to him of 250 dollars a year, and in 1816 a vote was passed, allowing him 250 dollars a year while he should supply the Pulpit. He is now willing to relinquish 150 dollars of this additional allowance, to relieve him from preaching half the time— The proposal is to raise by subscription about an equal amount, and to employ occasional Candidates, at ten dollars a day, with some further charges which for half the year may amount to 300 dollars— There was much discussion upon this report without coming to any decision— And so with regard to making provision for payment of the debt, there were various proposals, but no conclusion— Mr Thomas Greenleaf at last reminded the Committee that neither of the subjects on which they had been deliberating had been inserted in the Warrant for calling the Parish Meeting, at the adjournment of which this Committee was appointed, and therefore nothing could be done with legal effect upon these Subjects, at the Meeting to which this Committee are to report— There are 30 pews yet unsold—appraised at a reduced valuation at 3750 dollars, but which cannot produce so much— It was proposed to sell them at Auction, but objected that they would not thus fetch 2000 dollars— A paper was handed round for making up a Subscription to purchase them for 3000 dollars to be held in common by the Subscribers— I subscribed to this paper 500 dollars, and an effort is to be made to get the Subscriptions filled, before the Parish Meeting next Monday, when the Committee are to report. It was agreed to report a recommendation that a Meeting should be called competent to take measures on the subjects irregularly referred to this Committee, and to state the substance of the conference with Mr Whitney— At near Sunset I came home. Charles was gone, and I spent the Evening till near Midnight, in writing.
27. VI Saturday.

We have yet sharp frosts every night— Mr Carr came and settled with me for his rent, making up an account against me, for supplies of nearly one half its amount— In all cases of dealings between a man reputed rich, and a man reputed poor, the rich man must be prepared to surrender every question of conflicting right or interest between them. He must never strain for his right, be it never so clear— He must submit to almost any imposition: for so sure as he makes a point with a poor man, so sure he will have the whole neighbourhood against him— This is the Law of dealing between the rich, or the reputed rich and the poor; never to be forgotten or overlooked. The remainder of this day, I was engaged in writing, diary, Letters, and otherwise, till the day was gone, and little or nothing accomplished. Towards evening I walked to Mr John Greenleaf’s where with his family I found Mrs Cranch, of Washington— Her youngest Son Christopher Pearce Cranch came last Summer to attend the Theological School at Cambridge— He had then not wholly recovered from a severe bilious fever. He had a return of it in the Fall, and is again now so unwell that he has been obliged to leave the theological School, and is here at his Uncle’s— His situation is somewhat precarious; and his mother comes to attend him. I came home early in the Evening, but found it impossible to write much, from weakness of the eyes.
28. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from Colossians 1.12. “Giving thanks unto the father, which hath made us meet to be partakers of the inheritance of the Saints in light: 13. Who hath delivered us from the power of darkness, and hath translated us into the kingdom of his dear Son: 14. In whom we have redemption through his blood, even the forgiveness of Sins.” and in the afternoon from
Jeremiah 13.23. [“]Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots? then may ye also do good, that are accustomed to do evil.”— The house was thin— The Seats of the Singers almost deserted. Mr Whitney gave his auditory a portion of his doctrines, which differ little from those of universal salvation but yet admitting a future state of retribution— The Sentiment of Religion itself is rapidly declining in this part of the Country— My Son Charles and his wife came out from Boston, and dined with me; and returned home this Evening— They promised to come out next Thursday to stay— Mr Thomas Greenleaf, his Son, E. Price, and Mr Daniel Greenleaf spent an hour of the Evening with me— I read a Sermon of Saurin; the ninth of the second Volume; upon the Passions: a very long discourse, which it must have taken at least three hours to deliver; and of which I hardly know what to think or say; except that it did not please me.
29. V. Monday.

The weather had been so cold all the week that I had found fires in my writing chamber indispensable— I made one this morning as usual, but by two this afternoon Fahrenheit’s Thermometer was at 91. The heat was scorching— I went imprudently into my Garden and Nursery; and in pruning my Trees, worked my self in half an hour into a burning fever. I retreated to the House, but could not recover the Temperature of comfort, for the remainder of the day— In the garden and Nursery I have eyes for nothing but my seedling trees, and trees coming up from the seeds— About one third of the seedling trees which I left last year standing, are dead— Many heaved out of the ground by the frost—literally uprooted— Of the transplanted trees, a double proportion dead— Of yearly seedlings a great many living; but crooked and ragged and misshapen so as not to be fit to look at— The Plum trees in the front yard, came this day into full blossom— No appearance yet of the seeds and Stones which I planted last Autumn in the Garden, but perhaps eight or ten Apple seeds, and kernels of cherry and of wild cherry, have opened their Cotyledons above the surface of the ground— The Horse Chesnuts grow almost in spite of extirpation— The English Oaks all turn to Scrubs— The exotics appear to be all dead— Mrs Adams my brother’s widow called and left a Letter for her Son the Midshipman, Joseph H. to be forwarded under cover to Commodore Patterson— Deacon Spear, Luther Spear and George Vesey were here—all upon small teazing concerns of which life is full, when there is nothing of more importance to engross attention and interest— George Vesey is to bring over the barn from the hill opposite the house, and place it by the side of the others— At four in the afternoon I attended the adjourned Parish-Meeting— Josiah Brigham Moderator— I made verbally the report from the Committee of 13. That nothing definitive can be done by the Parish upon the subjects referred to the Committee; those Subjects not having been inserted in the warrant, by which the Parish Meeting was called— The Committee therefore recommended a Resolution, that the Assessors be instructed to call a Meeting of the Parish, in the warrant for which shall be inserted the proposition to consider of measures to be taken for the payment of the debt due by the Parish— A Resolution to that effect was adopted at the motion of Noah Curtis, the Meeting to be held on Monday the 13th. of May, at four O’Clock P.M— Report was also made informally, of the conference between Mr Whitney and the Sub-Committee, but the Parish took no order upon that— Some alarm was expressed by Deacon Spear, as being entertained by individuals in the Parish, that a proposition would be made to raise an additional sum, for payment of the Parish debts, to that which has been voted for the current expenses of the year—that is 1200 dollars— Upon which Deacon Spear said it would depend whether several members of the Parish would leave it or not.
A vote was therefore proposed and adopted that no further sum should be assessed for the current expenses of the year— It appeared in the course of the Meeting that the Treasurer’s Accounts of the last year were in much disorder, and that the collector had not accounted for one quarter part of the Assessment of the year 1832.— The Alteration of the third Article of the Bill of Rights in the Constitution of the State, which has twice passed the Legislature, and will be adopted by the People next November will dissolve great numbers of Parishes in this Commonwealth, and very probably this one— I met here at this Meeting Bryant Newcomb, who told me he had been in the Mills Prison, in England during the Revolutionary War, and at Amsterdam in 1780 when my father was there. The meeting adjourned shortly before Sunset— I returned home, and with abstinence wrote till past ten in the Evening— Still with head-ache and feverish heat from the exposure of the Morning.
30. V:20. Tuesday.

The Summer heat continued through the Night, and I had little and broken rest—the feverish heat however and head ache subsided, and I was this morning, well enough for occupation. I was again obliged after breakfast to come in from the garden by the pressure of heat, but about noon the wind came round to the East, and the remainder of the day was cool— Mr Beale and Mr Edward Miller who resides in Boston paid me a morning visit, and after dinner a man came by the name of Allen—insane; who visited me about seven years since at Washington, and again I believe since— I received from him on my return here a long Letter dated at Medfield the 8th. of this Month— He complains of want of health both of body and mind—says he was kidnapp’d and abducted from Boston in 1822 and has been under grievous persecution ever since— His state of mind appears to be precisely the same that it was seven years ago. He said he had left his father’s house yesterday and was now going towards Dorchester I found that questions made him garrulous,—and as it was drawing towards night, advised him to proceed. He said something about his having formed in 1822. an attachment to David Hinckley’s daughter, which reminded me of some romantic adventure of hers about that time; but I have no distinct recollection of what it was— I took a short walk about dusk and spent the Evening in writing— Finished a 3d. Letter to Edward Livingston upon Masonry— Received one from S. L. Southard.

Day— The first ten days of the Month at Washington— The second ten—travelling thence to Quincy— The third ten, keeping house in Solitude at Quincy. My rising hour constantly at the average of five, which is now also the time of rising for the Sun— I devote the first half hour, or sometimes three-quarters, to exercise— Washing, foot-bath in cold water; and here, in making my own fire— Read 3. Chapters of the Bible, and write short notes upon them. Having lost eight days while travelling, I now read four chapters every morning till the lost time shall be redeemed. I breakfast between 8 and 9. Then read, write or take exercise until dinner, which I now take alone at two—then resume miscellaneous occupation and exercise till dusk— Then spend an hour or two till ten and sometimes eleven comes for retirement to my bed— In travelling, and in press of occupation my Diary always runs in arrear— So it has done since I left Washington, and it is but just now redeemed— My Correspondence is much in arrear and the Summer before me—may it not be unprofitably wasted—
